headline: New version of Coca-Cola will be made with cane sugar after Trump's push

raw.headline: New version of Coca-Cola will be made with cane sugar after Trump's push
raw.summary: A week after President Trump said Coca-Cola would change its recipe and drop high fructose corn syrup, Coke says it has a new drink coming.

headline: Coca-Cola to roll out cane sugar coke, which Trump says is his doing
summary: STORY: Donald Trump says it’s his doing.Coca-Cola confirmed Tuesday (July 22) that it plans to roll out a version of Coke sweetened with cane sugar for the U.S. market.The news comes just a week after Trump posted on social media that he had pushed for the change.“This will be a very good move by them”, he said, adding “you’ll see, it’s just better!”.Coke in the U.S. has been sweetened with corn syrup, though some other markets do use cane sugar.Experts say there’s no major difference between the two with regards to health, saying too much of either is bad for you.Now Coca-Cola says the new version will complement existing products.But it’s likely to drive up costs for the firm, with cane sugar more expensive than corn syrup.U.S. corn refiners have also complained that a switch will hurt demand for their product, and lead to more imports of sugar.Coca-Cola is also battling the impact of Trump’s trade wars.It has said it’s looking at using more plastic bottles, with metal for cans facing a 50% import tariff.The firm has also faced a boycott from Hispanic customers in the U.S. and Mexico, after a viral video showed the firm laying off Latino workers and reporting them to immigration officials.Reuters in February found no public evidence that the company had reported its migrant employees to ICE.Despite all that, Coca-Cola saw revenue rise 2.5% to just over $12.6 billion for the latest quarter, beating forecasts.Though the volume of drinks sold declined over the period, that was more than offset by a rise in prices.

raw.headline: Coca-Cola to roll out cane sugar coke, which Trump says is his doing
raw.summary: STORY: Donald Trump says it’s his doing.Coca-Cola confirmed Tuesday (July 22) that it plans to roll out a version of Coke sweetened with cane sugar for the U.S. market.The news comes just a week after Trump posted on social media that he had pushed for the change.“This will be a very good move by them”, he said, adding “you’ll see, it’s just better!”.Coke in the U.S. has been sweetened with corn syrup, though some other markets do use cane sugar.Experts say there’s no major difference between the two with regards to health, saying too much of either is bad for you.Now Coca-Cola says the new version will complement existing products.But it’s likely to drive up costs for the firm, with cane sugar more expensive than corn syrup.U.S. corn refiners have also complained that a switch will hurt demand for their product, and lead to more imports of sugar.Coca-Cola is also battling the impact of Trump’s trade wars.It has said it’s looking at using more plastic bottles, with metal for cans facing a 50% import tariff.The firm has also faced a boycott from Hispanic customers in the U.S. and Mexico, after a viral video showed the firm laying off Latino workers and reporting them to immigration officials.Reuters in February found no public evidence that the company had reported its migrant employees to ICE.Despite all that, Coca-Cola saw revenue rise 2.5% to just over $12.6 billion for the latest quarter, beating forecasts.Though the volume of drinks sold declined over the period, that was more than offset by a rise in prices.

headline: KO Q2 Deep Dive: Volume Declines Offset by Pricing and Margin Gains Amid Dynamic Environment
summary: Beverage company Coca-Cola (NYSE:KO) reported Q2 CY2025 results exceeding the market’s revenue expectations, with sales up 2.1% year on year to $12.62 billion. Its non-GAAP profit of $0.87 per share was 3.9% above analysts’ consensus estimates.

headline: Advent-backed NIQ raises $1.05 billion in US IPO
summary: Consumer insights company NIQ Global [NIQ.N], backed by investment firms Advent International and KKR, said on Tuesday it had raised $1.05 billion in its initial public offering in the United States. About 50 million shares were priced at $21 each in the IPO, valuing NIQ at $6.35 billion. The move sets the stage for the company's debut on the New York Stock Exchange on Wednesday, amid a wave of recent IPOs in a market that is showing signs of revival after a prolonged slowdown.
